title: Paradigms All The Way Down
summary:
Key ideas:
- The process of interpreting the world involves a combination of pre-existing ideas and actual experiences
- The interaction between facts and theories is bidirectional, and theory determines what facts are noticed
- Ideological change does not result from debunking one fact but rather from a paradigm shift or crisis of faith
- The structure used for interpreting the world is built into basic algorithms used by the brain

Key learnings:
- The structure used to interpret the world involves pre-existing ideas and experiences
- A theory determines what facts are noticed, and ideology does not change easily
- The brain uses certain algorithms for epistemology

Key questions:
- Why is the bidirectionality of facts and theories so important?
- What role do pre-existing ideas play in shaping our interpretation of the world?
- How do we effectively navigate paradigm shifts or crises of faith in order to change our ideology or theories?
